segments.text: Well, leading off of this last topic of the generality of the oceanographer, I'm wondering, since World War II, since the other sciences have become somewhat integrated in the study of oceanography and this somewhat of a generalized field, as opposed to the land sciences where people often are very specialized, would you say that there

that this is a new frontier where something can be approached in a better way than we have done with land in terms of pollution, for instance, having the overall look at things rather than the specialized look.
Yes.
Are we getting a second chance with our approach to this new frontier of the ocean as opposed to what we have done on land?
And how does that relate to it?
but generalized it.
Yes.
This is a topic that interests me very much.
You know, we really haven't used the ocean until this generation for much other than transportation and as a moat protecting us in wartime from other countries, from aggressors perhaps.
We like to think of it
those as being aggressors.

Today, of course, we face the real problem of utilizing the ocean for many, many purposes, not the least of which is developing a sand and gravel, which comes to be in short supply in many land areas.
And of course, petroleum, we well know.
The difficulty with
The ocean is that almost everyone that you can imagine identifies in some way with the ocean.
It's either that he hasn't seen it and he wants to see it someday, or he's been on it and has learned to love it, or he hates it because of certain things.
But at any rate, almost anyone you talk to identifies with the ocean.
Not so with the land.
We take this for granted.
All right.
Now, when it comes to using the ocean effectively, we have a very high degree of emotionality involved.
And it is here that I think our emotions really begin to take over.
In recent years, I've been rather heavily involved in public hearings.
dealing with leasing of the continental shelf for oil exploration and production.
And I have been involved in hearings for the disposal of certain kinds of industrial waste beyond the continental shelf.
And as a consequence, I've come to feel very strongly that there is a very definite pattern of public reaction.
to utilization of the ocean, much of which is unreal.
Now, for example, I won't hesitate a moment to say that I feel that it is the ocean that is far less valuable to us than the land.
And I feel that the air is much more important to us than the ocean.
For example, I'll make a
a heretical statement that I have thought about.
It isn't just off the cuff.

I think we could live without the ocean, but certainly we couldn't live for a moment without the air envelope, and we certainly shouldn't try to continue to destroy land surfaces in ways that we're doing today.
What do we get?
One percent of our food from the ocean even yet.
And with the population going up as it is, I doubt that we'll improve much on that.
If you've got 15 million new people, not replacement people, but new people a year in China alone, I don't really believe that we're going to increase the percentage take from the ocean.
We will increase the tonnage possible.
All right, what I'm saying is this.

I think the elimination or disposal of certain wastes from products that we consider to be critical to man, and only if they are considered to be very important, should be disposed of in the ocean rather than the land.
And furthermore, I think that if you wanted to trace the sanitary landfill approach back in history, you could go back to the Etruscans.

I think that you clearly could look at the man who threw a chicken bone over his back and kicked some dirt over it as a sanitary landfill approach, or those who lived in caves, the cave dwellers who covered with a fresh layer of earth.
So what I'm saying is we must utilize the full extent of our scientific knowledge of the ocean to make effective use of it
to continue to better man's life.
And if that does mean that we should effectively dispose of waste in the ocean, I think we should.
I think that some of this has been very unreasoned.
This isn't for rampant pollution of the ocean, but it is, I think, a very important thing that we utilize what we know
rather than the hearsay material that we get.
You've seen just recently in the Houston Post when Shell Chemical applied for an ocean dumping permit to continue dumping certain sludges from one of their wastewater treatment areas.
And a captain of a fishing vessel, I suppose a charter vessel, testified that the flower garden
a west flower garden reef, was now dead or dying.
And as a consequence of this, he held up a piece of coral, which he said all the coral used to be sparkling white.
And now when he looked down in the waters, all he saw was a brown blob.
Well, not realizing, of course, that white coral that he sees underwater is dead and that the brown coral is living, if indeed he saw it.
And then he maintained the fish population is going down, and yet he what?
Indicated that on one day he took 13,000 pounds out of there in the good old days.
Well, a reef with that kind of food source can't sustain a population even migratory.
for that length of time, for any length of time with a fishing rate of that tax.
So this is what I think is the epitome of the misguided individual using his emotions, and they said he was almost in tears, to attempt to control a system he doesn't understand.
Now, this is inevitable, but the time
must continue that the scientist gets his information across as best he can.
I think this implies that more and more scientists must get into the real practical world rather than doing
purely esoteric research.
And I think this is happening.
I think in the last five years we've seen much more of it, of this movement out.
You know, you get it even in high sources.
A man like Jacques Cousteau, for example, says the sea is dying.
Well, Cousteau has a large public audience.
He says this without any scientific background whatsoever.
Really.
He's got knowledge, but not a scientific background to make an assertion such as this.
For example, Thor Heyerdahl said the same thing with his raft.
He'd look out every morning and see all this crud.
He was drifting with the current.
He was seeing the same crud day after day.
So this is one of those things that
We have no doubt that certain aspects of the sea are being handled very badly.
And again, we need to know what the sea can do for us.
Now that's a long answer to that.
It sounds almost like a harangue.
But I've been needled a long time on that subject, the last five years.
We are still not asking the ocean the right questions.
With all the money that's going into biological research right now on the outer continental shelf, we're still not getting at the real mechanism.
I believe that a large part of the ocean is sustained by the land, not by the primary productivity of the ocean itself.
So what question should we be asking the ocean?
Well, what we need to do is, as individuals, take a moratorium on running to sea to do research and attempt to design experiments at sea
with equipment that is properly designed to give us the kind of quantitation we need to understand the system.
Right now, we can make conceptual models of what's going on in the ocean.
And yet, we can't quantify it to produce a mathematical model that makes much sense yet.
And yet, this is going to be necessary in order to manage
the neuritic or inshore aspects of the seed.
Is this due to a sparsity of sampling or a too narrowing of the type of sampling that's being done?
Yes, a little bit.
The narrow approach, not necessarily too little.
There were good samples.
And the fact that we really don't have
very good equipment even yet.
Ten years ago, you could scarcely get a piece of equipment to work in deep water that wasn't in operation in 1890.
And I think that sort of points up what I'm talking about.
And yet most of us are not engineers that can do some of the things we should do.
We need to have
a greater input from engineering in this field, I think, to aid in that development.
Well, what is, then, the benthic skimmer?
Skimmer?
Skimmer, I'm sorry.
Oh, yeah.
The benthic skimmer was, well, several students and I designed an all-metal device which could be pulled rather rapidly over the bottom of the

to cut into the sediments at a predetermined depth and store the organisms in side pockets in the cod end out of the main stream of water so that we could get them by virtue of the speed we were pulling, which would overcome their speed,
since we felt a lot of organisms were escaping us because of that.
And yet, we could protect them from the main slipstream and thus bring these more delicate creatures up.
It worked well enough, but my time in deep water, I've got all the data I need to finish this book.
And if I've got any years left after that,
I've got one or two things that I hope to do in the Gulf of Mexico before the 200-mile limit goes into effect, since I think this is going to create some real problems for oceanographic research.
I think it's inevitable that it will go in, and I think it will mean that the paperwork
before going to sea will be perhaps a year or two leap time before you can go out to sea and do what you want, if indeed you can do it then.
Could you describe the Carnegie conference in 1951?
Who was there, whose idea was it, and what was your 51-52 really, and what you were trying to accomplish or do there?
Yes.
I was asked in the spring of 51 by John Gardner, who was then at the Carnegie Institute of New York, to take the place of someone else who was going to lead a symposium.
I'd forgotten who that other individual was, but at any rate, through illness, I had to give up the plan.
So what they wanted to do was attempt to bridge the gap between the foremost research activities going on in this country and the high school.

they felt that the universities had a pretty good input into this and that that information could get to the university student, but it was not getting to the high school where most scientists are really formed.
Most of them begin in the high school.
And it was felt then that there should be a way of doing this.
They hadn't worked out any protocol or any scenario at all.
And so I, because of, again, certain things that I had done in pre-medical education, this sort of stuff, was asked if I'd do this.
I indicated, yes, I would give it a try.
So what I did was sit down and decide who were the,
foremost scientists in the United States that could contribute to certain aspects of knowledge and began to invite them one by one to produce a program.
I rounded, sort of roughed out a program that I had in mind.
And then I had the problem of deciding how to select the high school teachers.
And first and foremost, I wanted to try to get those that were considered to be the best teachers.
I finally hit on the plan of asking students in various colleges and universities to nominate the people that they considered were the best teachers.
And I didn't limit it to the students then in the university, but also to those who had left the university and in retrospect said, these are the guys
the ladies or the men who had the greatest influence on me.
And I then invited 100 of these people to submit their credentials, and I selected 25 of what I consider to be the outstanding teachers.
And then went about getting the scientists to come.
You're asking me to go back 25 years without thinking much about it, but I do know that I had James Bonner, who was one of the foremost plant physiologists.
I invited Jack Calvin, who was then working on photosynthesis.
Jack Calvin had had a heart attack, so he sent Andrew Benson.
These men worked out
along with a few others in this country, photosynthesis.
And it was in that period that, for the first time, we understood what photosynthesis was.
And it was very cleverly done.
It was extremely clever experiments.
Andrew Benson is now at Scripps, the institution of oceanography, by the way.
He is not retired yet.
I got Knight.
who was the leading virologist of the time to come.
I got George Beadle to talk about.
And in 51, we didn't know DNA yet, but he brought DNA with him in 53 when he came back.
But to speak on his understanding of the gene, I got Hubble, who was the foremost

astronomer in the country to come and speak on his yardstick for measuring the age of the solar system, which, by the way, has been revised upwards several times, and he had just revised it upwards then.
Harrison Brown, who was one of the most stimulating men to speak on geophysics from the Earth.
Richard Feynman, who's still considered one of the
most inspiring physicists of all time.
Well, I got Edward Goldberg and Roger Revelle.
We went and visited Scripps for a couple of days.
We had some British oceanographers.
All these teachers were treated as if they were red carpet individuals, I tell you.
And they were good.
You know, it disabused me then that all the brains are going to be in the University of Science.
And it was not true.
These men and women were very stimulating to the speakers.
As a matter of fact, many of them became good friends.
And well, then we went to UCLA to the medical school that was developing.
And we were involved in the first heart surgery.
and saw all the machines and what have you that were devised to bypass the heart during these operations.
So it was a very stimulating experience, and I can't remember all of them.
But once in a while, I looked back on the teachers, and most of them now, of course, have moved up to supervisors or in charge of education in the state of California or what have you.
Unusual people.
I called it Progress and Horizons of Science, as I remember.
Fantastic experience.
I kept it, I think, three years.
Oh, no.
Yes.
Then National Science Foundation asked me to devise it for them.
And I went on into 58, as I remember now, come to think of it.
I had a long history of that.
I forgot about NSF calling.
It was because of that NSF asked me to come back and I took a job with them.
It was from that that led to your associate directorship and then your directorship at NSF.
Yeah.
Would you want to describe your work at NSF?
Yes.
That was an unsettling experience at first.
You know, coming from university and college work,

uh where you were always grappling with budgetary problems to be introduced uh one day to your supervisors and nsf and the next day told you had a budget of three or four million dollars and spend it wisely was an unsettling experience you know i ended up with uh where i was put in

charge orgy of special projects anything that came along that was unusual was given to me i unless i got oceanographic things i was sent by alan waterman who was then the director of the national science foundation uh for example in 1961 to century 21 in seattle to
to negotiate to take over the science exhibit, the buildings.
They put in a fantastic set of buildings out there.
So this is the World's Fair.
Yes.
Century 21 in Seattle.
Right.
And Commerce, by the way, that's where I met Spielhaus.
Spielhaus was the US commissioner of that exhibit.
And I dealt with him, as a matter of fact, in taking that building over, that set of buildings over,
from Commerce.
They were declared surplus by Commerce.
NSF took them over temporarily, and I negotiated that deal.

And then we handed them over to a private foundation, of which the head then, well, it was a big committee, University of Washington and so on involved, but the head man was a hotel man by the name of Carlson, who is now, I think, president of United Airlines.
But that was one of the kinds of things I did.

At that time, I was invited to President Kennedy, asked Waterman to nominate somebody to represent him in Argentina at an oceanographic conference where it was going to be, what will the great Nord Americano do for the South Americans in developing oceanography?
He was seriously contemplating going, and then it was considered that it would be too dangerous.
There were lots of communists there for him to go.
But for a nondescript like myself, it wasn't so bad.
So they sent me down there.
I got involved in this kind of special activity.
And then I developed new programs
to aid universities.
I gave, for example, a major grant to Duke University to beef up their engineering.
They'd been very poor.
To aid Duke in developing a marine science program.
And I created one of the first programs in hydrology in the United States and called together all of the leading

water people in the world to a conference at NSF where we debated what should be done and finally roughed out a program and instituted it in several institutions, not the least of which was the then-developed University of Arizona, which has come forth with a really outstanding hydrology program.
Matter of fact, I was offered a job at Cornell as a hydrologist.
The guy thought I knew so much from this meeting, which I didn't.
But that was the history of my life, a very special topic, very challenging, but a very exhausting work within a set.
And my wife, Linda, who of course has a degree in oceanography,
wanted me to get out of that administration.
And I think on the side, she wanted to get her degree, too.
And so it worked out pretty well, my coming here.
Dale Leeper came back to one or two of my conferences.
Dale was then chairman of this department.
And finally, as a result of this, he kept telephoning me about every other month saying, when are you going to come down and visit us and join our department?
So after a year, I
We liked what we saw.
And you didn't go then to SUNY at Stony?
Oh, in between I did go to SUNY.
I only stayed, I think, three months at SUNY.
It wasn't long.
Yes, it wasn't long.
I roughed out a program, picked a site for their marine development.
I carried my resignation around in my coat pocket, already stamped, ready to go.
And finally one day it got so bad, I just dropped it in the mailbox.
And after I dropped it, I phoned NSF and said, do you have an opening left that I could fill?
And they said, yes, we surely do.
You might have to take a demotion, but they won't be long before we promote you again.
Got in the car with my family that night in the middle of a snowstorm, drove to Washington, and went to work the next day.
